‘Why did you build such a small train?’ That was the frequent refrain facing Stefan Rosendahl and his Stadler colleagues as visitors to the InnoTrans trade show in Berlin got a first look at the new offering for Glasgow’s underground. Many visitors to the show, unfamiliar with the Subway’s unique four-foot track gauge and 3.4-metre tunnel diameter, were perplexed to find a train they could not stand up straight in.

This was a true debut outing – no-one had seen the new Subway train before. Mr Rosendahl, Senior Project Manager for the Swiss manufacturer, says the train was completed only two weeks prior to the show. But, with the debut outing promised, he says everyone at Stadler was fully geared up to ensure that deadline would be met. And Mr Rosendahl affirms that the Subway train is indeed both unique and special, while highlighting his deep respect for the previous generation of engineers who built the current stock.

The contract to build the new Subway fleet was awarded in March 2016. Strathclyde Partnership for Transport, which operates the Subway, opted to procure trains and signalling as a single package, with a £200 million deal awarded to a joint venture of Ansaldo STS and Stadler. Stadler will supply 17 new trains to replace the current fleet, which mostly dates from the late 1970s, while Ansaldo STS will be responsible for a new signalling system, telecoms and control centre. This is planned to facilitate a move to unattended train operation, with the Subway becoming the first system in the UK to operate routinely without any staff on board its trains.

With the joint venture in mind, Mr Rosendahl says integration of the new trains with the control system is a key interface. He highlights the importance of Stadler and Ansaldo STS knowing each other’s requirements and of commissioning systems together. As well as the new control system, Ansaldo STS will be responsible for fitting half-height platform screen doors, again requiring strong co-operation with the rolling stock manufacturer. At the same time, throughout the design process Stadler engaged with its customer, SPT, on refinements to the look and characteristics of the new trains.

So with this being a unique project, what were the key challenges of designing the new Subway train? ‘Usually when we are going through the design phase and talking about tolerances they are in centimetres, but here we are really talking about millimetres’ Stefan Rosendahl explains. Most of the 24-volt equipment is contained beneath seat bases, with higher-voltage equipment under the vehicle floors. ‘We have a lot of cabling on this train – around 15km on a 39-metre-long train, most of which is under the floor in a specially designed cable duct’ Mr Rosendahl adds.

The current Subway trains run in three-car formations, but Stadler is replacing them with four-car units, formed of two articulated pairs. Mr Rosendahl explains these pairs of two cars each are more or less identical; indeed, in the interior there is no difference between them, but in the centre of the train there is a key difference in equipment beneath the vehicle floor; one half contains a battery used to power on-board systems while the other features equipment for the Ansaldo STS control system.

FOUR CARS NOT THREE

So why build a four-car unit, not a three-car one as is currently the case? Mr Rosendahl explains this is linked to the requirement in the specification for the new fleet to incorporate through gangways between the vehicles. This drove the decision to have two longer outer vehicles of 12.1 metres each, with the inner vehicles shorter at 7.5 metres.

‘The movements between the carriages are very intensive’ Mr Rosendahl says. ‘For an articulated vehicle you are working in terms of two-dimensional rather than three-dimensional movement. Having two shorter vehicles in the centre of the train reduces the movement on the gangways.’

Another feature of the Glasgow Subway is some notoriously tight curves – of 130-metre radius on the system itself but down to 50 metres within Broomloan depot. Mr Rosendahl says noise and comfort will be improved on the new fleet as a result of the four-car arrangement, as well as the incorporation of rubber elements in the wheels and the trains having air suspension.

Possibly the greatest test of this last characteristic will come from the Glasgow Rangers football fans who board trains at Ibrox after matches. They are known to test the trains’ suspension in a self-explanatory practice known as ‘bouncy bouncy’, certainly a unique challenge for any manufacturer to deal with!

Each train is powered by eight 103kW engines distributed throughout the formation. This should improve performance compared to the current fleet, although the tight curves of the Subway mean the impact on journey times will be marginal.

In terms of the interior, SPT was clear it wanted to retain orange poles and handrails, in homage to the system’s ‘Clockwork Orange’ nickname. The seating moquette is also a nod to the Subway’s heritage, with the concentric circles representing the inner and outer circles, again with suitable splashes of orange.

A new feature is the provision of electronic passenger information displays within the saloons. There are two at each vehicle end – Mr Rosendahl says the intention is for one to display route information such as the next station, and the other to be used for special messages or advertising. However, he says SPT can configure these screens as required, for example by using both screens to display emergency information.

Other on-board features include spaces for wheelchairs and pushchairs (although only two of the Subway’s 15 stations are fully accessible) and CCTV. Each train has six doors per side, as on the current fleet, to facilitate rapid boarding and alighting; the spacing of doors is also similar to that on the current fleet.

The system’s limited gauge means providing air conditioning on the new trains was not practical. However, Mr Rosendahl notes the Subway’s tunnels maintain an ambient temperature of between 16 and 19 degrees, cooler than typically found on other metro systems.

As with many projects, Stadler is utilising multiple sites to produce the new Subway trains. Main construction is at the Altenrhein plant in Switzerland, but bogies come from the sister site at Bussnang.

Mr Rosendahl reports that the train on display at InnoTrans is the only one built so far, with Stadler using experience from the maiden unit to aid construction going forward. After a pause, construction of the second train is now underway.

Once the third train is built there will be a further pause in production. This is because the first three of the 17 trains are to be used for type testing of all features needed for a safe, fully automated operation. As there is no suitable site with the Subway’s unique track gauge on the continent, this must by necessity take place in the UK, and an old test track on land owned by SPT behind Broomloan depot is to be revived for this purpose.

Mr Rosendahl explains two test tracks will be built, one of 150 metres and the other of 750 metres. The former will be used for straightforward dynamic running (to put this length in context, a single circuit of the Subway is 10.6km). The first train must accumulate 2,000 miles of fault-free running, with subsequent units needing to achieve 500 miles.

The longer circuit will be used to test the interfaces with the new Ansaldo systems, such as the new signalling and platform screen doors. With three trains available for the testing process, two can typically be on the test tracks while a third will undergo static testing. The whole testing process is expected to take around two years.

Mr Rosendahl says the first train is due to arrive in the UK by the end of the year; delivery will be by road, half a train at a time.

Trains on the Subway are already driven automatically, but with a driver opening and closing the doors from the cab at the front; this is GoA 2 in the scale of Grades of Automation (see box) and is similar to the methods employed on London Underground lines which use automatic operation. GoA 3 is akin to current Docklands Light Railway operation, where trains are driven automatically but a train captain is located in the passenger saloons rather than in a cab. Moving to GoA 4, where all functions are completely unattended, will be a first for the UK. It is also the first time Stadler has built trains for a driverless system.

Rather than retrofitting the existing signalling system to the new trains, the new Ansaldo signalling will operate in parallel with the current equipment while both the new and old fleets are in service. The challenge here is that both the new trains and signalling must work together from the start, reinforcing Mr Rosendahl’s statement about the importance of the joint venture partners working together. Once the full fleet is in place, the legacy system can be eliminated and the migration phase to full automation, with installation of platform screen doors, can begin.

GoA 3 Driverless train operation (DTO, attendant on board but not necessarily in the cab)

GoA 4 Unattended train operation (UTO, no driver or attendant required for normal operation)

Full automation removes the need for a driver’s cab, but clearly this will still be required in the initial stages.

The train displayed at InnoTrans showcased a temporary cab at one end but none at the other, giving a glimpse of how trains will look through both phases of the migration. Even when the temporary cabs are removed, controls will still be required for manual driving within the depot, and these are contained beneath a seat at the end of the train.

Mr Rosendahl explains a notable change compared to the original specification has been improvement in the temporary cab, including provision of a full driver’s seat. A glass partition wall will be fixed to handrails within the train to segregate the temporary cab from the passenger saloon; Mr Rosendahl says it will take around two days to install or remove this.

The move to full automation has had several interesting implications. One is the precise maximum speed of the trains – 58km/h. Mr Rosendahl explains in any system there is a need to add a tolerance to allow for error, but in the case of fully automatic operation this is higher than in manual mode and is based on a worst-case scenario.

In another first for Stadler, more stringent fire protection standards must be adhered to where fully automatic operation is concerned. Mr Rosendahl says the choice of materials is of prime importance here, highlighting a particular challenge in selecting materials for the floor and seat fabric. On a related point, the seats are from Transcal, an example of Stadler endeavouring to use UK suppliers where possible.

As is normal for an underground metro, safety dictates evacuation must be possible through the cab in the event of an emergency (or, where there is no temporary cab, through the end of the saloon). Beyond the emergency door there is a step and handrail; Mr Rosendahl says the door is released automatically by the Ansaldo control system when required. The normal method of evacuation is to bring a second train alongside and create a closed gangway from one unit to another, with trains able to couple together in degraded mode, although Mr Rosendahl says the design accounts for all eventualities.

SPT will continue to be responsible for maintenance of the new fleet, but with support from Stadler. Mr Rosendahl explains development of the required knowledge will be based on a ‘train the trainer’ philosophy, in co-operation with Ansaldo STS. Like most modern trains, the new Subway vehicles are software-reliant, and SPT staff will need to adapt to the far more advanced diagnostic system for resolving issues on the new fleet.

At present 12 trains are rostered for Subway operation at peak hours (based on 36 out of 41 carriages forming 12 three-car trains). With the new fleet this will rise to a maximum of 16, enabling SPT to increase the frequency of trains to every three minutes at the busiest times. Mr Rosendahl says such levels of availability are regularly achieved with other fleets.

The Subway’s Broomloan depot is being upgraded to accommodate the new fleet, including an extension to the stabling shed, provision of a new train wash, a new lifting road and a wheel lathe; presently wheelsets are sent to Wabtec’s Kilmarnock facility for turning

On October 8, NYK Shipmanagement Pte. Ltd.* appointed Indonesia seafarer Asep Dadang Kurniawan as the first Indonesian captain of an NYK LNG carrier.

Captain Asep Dadang Kurniawan has been a member of the NYK Group since 2002 and initially served on container ships and chemical tankers. From 2008, he transitioned to LNG carriers, eventually becoming an experienced navigator. He is now being appointed to the position of captain of an LNG carrier that provides transportation services for the Tangguh LNG project.**

Since shipping for the Tangguh LNG project began in 2008, NYK has been working to foster high-quality Indonesian seafarers for this project. In fact, since full-scale domestic transportation within Indonesia started under this project in 2014, NYK has had a long-term plan in place for training senior Indonesian seafarers in anticipation of the booming LNG transportation in the country.

Through the NYK Maritime College,*** which is a unique program featuring unified requirements for seafarers regardless of nationality, NYK has worked hard to appoint Indonesians to senior positions on high-risk ships.**** The promotion of Asep Dadang Kurniawan to captain of an LNG carrier can be said to be a concrete result of this initiative.

NYK will continue to train excellent Indonesian seafarers and contribute to the development of the Tangguh LNG project and, by extension, the Indonesian maritime industry.

Captain Asep Dadang Kurniawan’s comment:

 “In this moment I would like to say thank you to the company for giving me trust to become First-Indonesian master on LNG Ship. This is big responsibility for me to be a master on LNG Ship, but I will do with my best to ensure safe operation of the ship. I hope Company will continue supporting me and give opportunity to other Indonesian officer.”

On February 3, NYK released the NYK Group ESG Story,***** which aims to further integrate ESG into the company’s management strategy and promotes activities that contribute to the achievement of the SDGs (Sustainable Development Goals) through business activities. To strongly promote ESG management, NYK will continue the training of high-quality seafarers and the creation of employment for them, in addition to new value creation as a sustainable solution provider.

* NYK Shipmanagement Pte. Ltd.

 Established in 2001, NYK Shipmanagement Pte. Ltd. is a wholly owned NYK Group subsidiary based in Singapore. As the core of the Group’s ship management, the company dispatches seafarers to and manages ships operated by the NYK Group.

** Tangguh LNG project

 In this project, natural gas that is produced in the Berau, Wiriagar, and Muturi mining areas in Papua, Indonesia, is liquefied and shipped mainly to Japan, Mexico, and South Korea.

*** NYK Maritime College

 A training program started in 2006 to provide a wide range of onshore and onboard skills and high expertise necessary for global success based on NYK requirements that specify the knowledge and technical requirements required of seafarers on board NYK vessels.

**** High-risk ships

 Ships such as tankers and LNG carriers that transport dangerous goods.

***** NYK Group ESG Story

 A guideline detailing concrete efforts to integrate ESG into management strategies of the NYK Group. Details: NYK Issues the NYK Group ESG Story

Richard Turner (Full Name: Richard Alexander Turner), Former Athletic Trainer For Two High Schools In San Fernando Valley, Pleaded No Contest To Felony Charges of Sexually Assaulting Teen Girls

VAN NUYS, CALIFORNIA (May 14, 2024) – A former athletic trainer identified as Richard Turner has pleaded no contest after being arrested on suspicion of multiple felony charges of sexually assaulting 12 teen girls.
Los Angeles County officials are saying the defendant entered the plea during a hearing to determine if there was enough evidence to go to trial. So far, Richard Turner has pleaded no contest to 13 counts of sexually assaulting 12 girls.
Prosecutors have said that he will likely spend the last of his days in prison. The defendant was initially facing 21 felony charges for interactions with students that took place between 2017 to 2022.
Prior to this time period, a student at Van Nuys High School said that Richard Turner touched her inappropriately. Prosecutors have said that the plea deal saves the victims from the traumatic experience of testifying at trial.
Liability For Sexual Abuse By Athletic Coaches
A large portion of the sexual abuse that takes place in schools involves athletic trainers and coaches. According to Business Insider, “The difference between coaches and academic teachers is that coaches might have access to students in unique ways. School coaches are tasked with guiding student-athletes through difficult physical maneuvers. That often means that coaches have to physically place their hands on a student to either evaluate a complaint of pain or demonstrate a way to complete an action.” There are a number of signs that school officials should look for to indicate that coaches may be engaging in misconduct.

Coaches may engage in overly personal interactions with students in ways that seem excessive. 
Coaches may be secretive about their interactions with students. 
Coaches may ignore or cross professional boundaries. 
Coaches may be the subject of past complaints of misconduct.

Schools have a legal obligation to protect students from the sexual predation of their employees. Consider, for example, Taylor v. Oakland Scavenger Co., 17 Cal. 2d 594 [110 P.2d 1044], “It is the duty of the school authorities to supervise at all times the conduct of the children on the school grounds and to enforce those rules and regulations necessary to their protection.” School officials are also mandated reporters. They can be held criminally liable for failing to report reasonably suspected instances of child abuse. There are many ways that a school may have failed to properly protect a student from sexual abuse.

A school may have failed to conduct thorough background checks. 
A school may have failed to adequately supervise the students in their care. 
School officials may have failed to report a suspected instance of misconduct. 
School officials may have failed to set clear guidelines between faculty and students.

Much of the sexual abuse that takes place in schools is preventable. It is much more likely at schools that refuse to accept responsibility for what is going on. Sadly, though, schools will often do everything that they can to deny responsibility if students in their care are sexually abused. Any person who is sexually abused by a school official does have rights. They are able to seek some measure of justice through a civil claim.
Getting Legal Help After Los Angeles County School Sexual Abuse

It is our sincere hope that the school district will implement additional measures to prevent abuse. There needs to be accountability across the board for what took place.
Have you or someone that you care about been sexually abused at school in Los Angeles County? Our team of sexual abuse attorneys is here to help you. We are committed to getting survivors justice and holding school districts accountable for their negligence. Whether you just have legal questions or need any type of support, we are here for you. No one was injured or killed Friday morning when Sierra Northern Railway tracks came apart in a saturated gully and two empty tank cars weighing 30 to 35 tons each derailed at 5 to 10 miles per hour on Hospital Road, next to the U.S. Post Office on South Washington Street in downtown Sonora.
The screeching sounds of heavy metal tearing apart wood railroad ties and thick pavement scared some witnesses, as the trailing tank car veered 15 to 20 feet off the tracks and damaged five vehicles parked next to the Post Office.
The derailed train then chopped down a metal crossing cantilever over South Washington Street. That’s where the last two cars came to rest, blocking South Washington Street from 9:20 a.m. through at least Friday afternoon.
Sonora Police Cpl. Thomas Brickley said the estimated time for reopening South Washington Street was 7 p.m. Two Caterpillar bulldozers on tracks were among the heavy equipment being used to move the derailed train cars.
Ken Beard, chief executive officer of Sierra Northern Railway, said in a phone interview Friday afternoon that the cause of the crash remained under investigation.
At 10 a.m. Friday, about 40 minutes after the derailment, a pink piece of plastic tape with “57 ½” and “Drainage Issue” handwritten on it lay on the tracks where one rail began to wrench free from its moorings about 100 yards uphill from the Post Office.
Beard said the tracks in that location were first put in back in 1897, though they have been upgraded multiple times over the past 126 years and are on a schedule to be upgraded again.
“We got a grant to upgrade from Riverside to Standard,” Beard said. “About a month ago, our track inspectors walked the whole line out there.”
The inspectors marked that area for improving the 57 ½ inch gage to a standard 56 ½ inch gage, Beard said. The railroad cars used on the line can run on gages from 56 to 58 inches wide.
Linda Darby, 63, of Sonora, saw and heard the derailment without realizing at least one tank car was completely off the tracks as it passed her vehicle on Hospital Road.
“I was just waiting here for the train to pass,” Darby said. “It was near the end of the train I saw all this smoke. I thought it was smoke. You couldn’t see through it. I didn’t want to breathe it. It was squeaking pretty loud, it sounded like metal on metal. And then all these people were coming out here looking and I thought ‘what are they looking at.’ The last car came by making all this noise and I didn’t even realize it was off the tracks.”
Anthony Hernandez, of Avery, was at work at the Sonora Post Office when it happened. He didn’t see it, but he ran outside when coworkers outside loading packages into trucks began shouting, “Oh snap, the train’s derailing! The train’s derailing!”
“I came out and my car was already messed up,” Hernandez said of the used 2020 four-wheel-drive Jeep Wrangler Unlimited Sport he’d just bought in August, which he estimates is now totaled. “It’s the only vehicle I own for my family.”
Hernandez’ Jeep got dragged 20 to 30 feet from its legal parking spot on Hospital Road and smashed into a sign in the Post Office front parking lot on South Washington Street.
By 11:15 a.m. Friday, Hernandez had spent nearly two hours solid on the phone with insurers, trying to get his claim in and secure a tow truck and a replacement rental vehicle.
Post Office employee Reggie Van Sleet was inside working when he heard coworkers start talking about a derailment.
“A friend of mine came running in and he said ‘Reggie, your truck’s destroyed. A train just derailed.’ I thought he was joking,” Van Sleet said. “It was chaos out here. My truck, the red one, was sitting right up in front of the intersection.”
His Chevrolet Avalanche got battered and pushed more than 50 feet from where it was parked. The wheels of the trailing derailed tank car left distinct cuts in the pavement of Hospital Road from the point it derailed along its path veering 15 to 20 feet from the tracks, to where it came to rest on South Washington Street.
Postal worker Charity Stevens said she was out on her route delivering packages when a coworker called and told her about the derailment and told her that her vehicle parked on Hospital Road did not get hit. She was relieved.
“Mine’s good. Whew!” Stevens said. “I’m sorry for everybody else. I’m glad no one was hurt. That’s crazy it derailed because it doesn’t seem like it goes that fast through here. They come through every day. Usually lumber. Maybe 5 miles an hour. They blow their horn really loud.”
Beard said the company has insurance to cover such damage to private property.
David Rupert, a spokesman for the U.S. Postal Service, said that the Sonora Post Office would be fully operational Saturday and all routes would be delivered. He asked people to consider using an alternate location if they need to mail something out to avoid impacting emergency workers or delivery service.
Sonora Mayor Mark Plummer praised the city fire and police departments’ response to the derailment. He walked the section of tracks that came apart within an hour of the derailment and said it was fortunate that the tank cars were empty, because they are used to carry propane.
Sonora Fire Capt. Brittan Gregory said the train contained four flat cars loaded with covered materials and four tank cars directly behind them. Beard said the flat cars were hauling lumber.
Beard said the company typically runs trains through Sonora three to four days per week during the winter due to the increased demand for propane. He said they mainly haul lumber during the summer a couple days per week.
Derailments on the Oakdale-based company’s tracks are rare, Beard said, but the previous two wetter-than-normal winters have caused more issues than they’ve typically seen in the past.
“The ground gets soft, the ties get soft and it’s hard to hold the rail engaged,” he said.
The company previously had a minor derailment of an empty tank car in Jamestown on March 16 last year. That incident caught attention because it occurred a little over a month after a Norfolk Southern Railway train carrying hazardous materials derailed in Ohio and caused a massive environmental disaster that forced the evacuation of hundreds of residents in the nearby town of East Palestine.
According to federal data, as many as three trains derail per day in the United States, with half of those carrying hazardous materials, though relatively few cause disasters such as the one seen in Ohio.
Beard noted that Sierra Northern Railway is currently in the midst of a six-year plan to rehabilitate the entire 55-mile freight line of railroad tracks between Riverbank and Sonora.
In June 2019, the Modesto Bee reported the company received a nearly $17.4 million federal grant for the nearly $36 million project that will involve new ties, rails and road crossings. The rest of the cost would be covered by the company, the Bee reported.
The Tuolumne County Board of Supervisors voted to support the company’s original grant application for the project in 2017.

Both suspects arrested in Brentwood 24-Hour fitness fatal shooting
August 28, 2022 By Publisher 3 Comments Brentwood SWAT at Myrtlewood Court home in Antioch. Tauane following his arrest on Wednesday, August 24, 2022. Photos: BPD
Brentwood teen arrested, first; Pittsburg man arrested in Antioch last week; victim from Antioch was innocent bystander
Faatino Tauane. Photo: BPD
By Brentwood Police Department
During the course of the investigation into the deadly shooting that occurred at the 24-Hour Fitness in Brentwood on Thursday, August 11, 2022, at approximately 1:54 a.m., Brentwood Police investigators positively identified 20-year-old Pittsburg resident Faatino Arona Tauane as the second shooter in this case.
On Wednesday, August 24, 2022, at approximately 4:45 a.m., Tauane was peacefully taken into custody at a home in the 900 block of Myrtlewood Drive in Antioch. He was later booked at the Martinez Detention Facility for murder. To date, one firearm has been recovered and the vehicle Tauane used to flee the scene is now in police custody. A second firearm used in the shooting remains outstanding.
On Friday, August 26, 2022, the Contra Costa County District Attorney’s Office charged Tauane with one count of murder with enhancements and additional felonies.
On Thursday, August 11, 2022, the first of two suspects detained during the early stages of the investigation had been positively identified as one of the shooters who was wounded during the altercation. The suspect, a 17-year-old Brentwood resident was booked into the Contra Costa County Juvenile Detention Center for murder. His name is being withheld due to age. The second suspect was released from police custody after it was determined he was not a shooter.
The decedent has been identified as, 21-year-old Antioch resident, Cesar Arana. Our hearts go out to the family and friends impacted by his untimely death.
Arana was an innocent bystander not involved in the initial altercation. He was struck by gunfire while trying to help a person who had fallen to the ground during a physical fight outside.
Additionally, our agency would like to thank those who came forward with additional video footage and the staff at 24 Hour Fitness for their full cooperation throughout the entire investigation.
According to localcrimenews.com, Tauane was also arrested by Pittsburg Police in December 2021, for carrying a concealed weapon in a vehicle and when not the registered owner.
Anyone with information regarding the outstanding firearm or any additional information related to this investigation is asked to contact Detective Greene at 925-809-7797.
Allen D. Payton contributed to this report.

VERNON (CBSLA) -- John Moss was driving along Long Beach Avenue at 55th Street in Los Angeles on March 2, on his way to pick up his work partner early in the morning. He says he made a left hand turn, across a set of L.A. Metro train tracks — and had no idea a train was speeding his way.

"No indications that the lights were blinking and I didn't hear any bells, it was too late," he said. "I looked to the left and a train just hit me. Next thing I knew, I basically woke up in the hospital."

Security footage shows the incident. The train hits Moss' BMW at full speed as he tries to make his turn.

"It's a miracle that I'm standing here and I have nightmares about this," he said. "I'm very lucky to be alive."

The 60-year-old suffered broken bones and major internal injuries. He said he continues to deal with pain, but he is thankful to be alive to tell his story.

"Fortunate for me, I got hit on the left side of my car and the train pushed me back out and that's how the car did not end up on the tracks," he said. "If I didn't survive that accident, no one would know about this."

He said he believes his accident could have been prevented, and he wants to see changes before other drivers are hurt or killed.

"I was allowed to enter the intersection and there was no gate to stop me from entering the intersection," he said.

A spokesperson for the L.A. Metro said they performed a post-accident inspection their equipment and found that all warning lights, crossing gates, and warning bells were functioning at the time of the accident. They also said the driver made an illegal left turn and used the wrong traffic lane to circumvent the lowered crossing gate.

"Regardless of what they're saying about I entered on the wrong lane, no one should be allowed to enter period," Moss said about the statement.

L.A. Metro said drivers need to strictly follow the safety measures already in place. But, Moss said the crossing gate should be extended all the way across to prevent drivers from turning onto the tracks completely.

"They should've came up with the conclusion that this is a very dangerous intersection," he said. "What happened to me, it's easy to happen to someone else. Those changes are a necessity."

SACRAMENTO (CBS13) — The standoff outside the California Capitol where a driver parked his car in the middle of L Street on Monday brought back memories of an incident 15 years earlier that changed security around the building.
On Jan. 16, 2001, Mike Bowers, 37, drove an 18-wheeler into the south side of the Capitol. A CBS13 news crew happened to be working on a story nearby when the crash happened and filed a report.
What follows is the report from that night, as well as one a month later detailing the California Highway Patrol's investigation into the incident.
------
THE CRASH
A CBS13 photographer and reporter were on the west side of the California Capitol when they heard a noise from the south side.


What we heard and quickly saw, others saw before us, as the big rig driver drove straight into the Capitol.
CBS13 spoke to three witnesses that night who described what happened.
"All of a sudden, I look to my left as I was passing the Capitol and I saw a semi—what looked to be a semi truck—pulled into the step area. It looked like it had either backed in or smashed in. I didn't see any movement in the truck. And all of a sudden, boom, fire. And I thought, 'My God, they're bombing the Capitol," the first witness said.
"I was standing on the corner of 11th and O [streets], and I saw the semi go by really fast. And I thought, isn't there a stop sign there? I noticed he was going really, really fast. And then I hear this big boom, then I look around the corner, then there's fire," the second witness said.


Similar accounts surfaced of the man behind the wheel driving around a several square block area, speeding down 11th Street to apparently gain momentum.
"We saw a big trailer going by. He must have been going 65 mph. I didn't see what direction he went, but I know when he hit N Street, there's only one way you can go, and that's eastbound," the third witness said.
Minutes later, the big rig accelerated again, going full-bore into the state Capitol.
"This time, he had to be flying at least 75 mph, and he just went through the stop sign, and luckily the light rail stopped. If not, he would have took the light rail. He went to through the stop sign, went through the lights, I saw him bounce one, the second bounce was straight into the Capitol and it went up in flames," the third witness said.
Authorities on hand describe the driver's actions as a deliberate criminal act, which now leaves a footnote of a suicide attack in the history of California's Capitol.
-----
THE INVESTIGATION
"When they heard about him next, it would be his death, and it would be a very grandiose act on his part."


That's what 37-year-old Mike Bowers told his friends before he took his own life. On Jan. 16, 2001, the Riverside County man drove his 78,000-pound 18-wheeler into the south entrance of the Capitol at a speed of 46 mph.
"He was very unhappy, made some—not threats, I don't want to indicate that—but voiced discontent with the California government, as well the governor of the state of California."
The California Highway Patrol released a three-volume, 77-page summary in February 2001 concluding Bowers acted alone and was sober at the time of the crash. According to the report, Bowers had drug, petty theft, battery and DUI convictions. In 1986 and 1991, he was placed in two state mental hospitals. In the past decade, he began a friendship with the Aryan Brotherhood and created an organization called New Order of the World, calling himself the king.
Bowers was unable to hold down a job until he was hired by a trucking company in March 2000. Even his driver's training instructor recommended Bowers be terminated.
"The training instructor immediately called back to their dispatcher and indicated [Bowers] could not drive the truck, that he was very concerned, would not put him in a truck, and he was overruled and [Bowers] was given a job. That training instructor left the company employment at that particular time."
The report also says Bowers nearly missed an inbound light-rail train by 30 seconds and an outbound light-rail train by 45 seconds, with each train carrying some 180 passengers.
"It was just by accident he missed that train. You could not see it coming down the road at the speed he was traveling."

CORONA, Calif. (KABC) -- Wild hogs are running rampant in Corona and residents say it's becoming a growing problem that's posing a threat to the safety of families and pets all across the area.

"The pigs have been coming," said Corona resident Judy Gardner. "They came here to my house on Halloween night, and then they came back on Veterans Day, and probably going to be here for Thanksgiving.

Homeowners have captured the hogs - who have caused significant damage to people's lawns - on home surveillance cameras wandering through neighborhoods.

"I came down and saw the damage and kind of immediately knew that it was the wild boars kind of tormenting our neighborhood," said resident Julie Chiasson.

City officials say they're aware of the issue and say it's been on their radar for quite some time.

In July, the Corona City Council had an official with the California Department of Fish and Wildlife discuss possible options to deal with the feral pig population, which included allowing homeowners and others the ability to hunt them.

"The options are basically to do trapping or remain the status quo, and unfortunately the status quo, for most, folks is pretty destructive," said Corona vice mayor Wes Speake.

To learn more on the city of Corona's resident services, visit the city's website.

The Angeles National Forest offers the 10 million residents of neighboring Los Angeles County a true escape from the urban environment. Covering over 650,000 acres and with elevations ranging from 1,200 to over 10,000 feet, the forests spectacular scenery and range of recreational activities on offer from camping and fishing to hiking, skiing and swimming attracts about four million visitors each year.
With such a vast amount of traffic making its way up and down the mountain, accidents do happen and vehicles sometimes end up over the roads edge on the slopes of the mountains.
Last July, Los Angeles County Fire Department (LACoFD), Los Angeles County Sheriffs Department (LASD) mountain search and rescue, U.S. Forest Service, San Bernardino Fire Department, California Highway Patrol and other local agencies trained together for three days to prepare for such over the side rescue scenarios. The training simulated accidents including cars, trucks, motorcycles and mass-casualty buses and vans. Each scenario was different, with varying levels of difficulty, but all integrated a multi-agency emergency response.
The training saw participation from ground and air operations, with LACoFD providing a Bell 412EP and a paramedic crew, while LASD provided Air Rescue 5 its Sikorsky SH-3H Sea King, along with a paramedic crew.
The objective of the exercise was to have a multi-agency drill involving those agencies responsible for the mountainous areas of Los Angeles County, and to review operational differences in procedure, so that solutions could be found for any problems identified. On the air operations side, the commanders wanted to make sure operational procedures and interactions were understood by the rescue units and the helicopter crews.
Over the three days of training, multiple scenarios were set up, from a single motorcycle over the side to a large multi-casualty bus crash with over 20 victims. After ground search and rescue personnel began working at the scene, LACoFD Copter 12 would hoist a paramedic down to the scene. Then, after a victim was packaged they would be hoisted into the helicopter for transport.
On the days LASD Air Rescue 5 could attend (it was called away for some real-world operations), it performed hoist rescues and lowered paramedics to the scene of the scenario. The LASD will soon be receiving the first new AS-332L1 Super Pumas a helicopter that should provide increased performance in the hot and high conditions in which the unit normally operates.
In a mass-casualty accident, such as the Metrolink train crash in 2008, multiple helicopters would be requested to assist the response. Between LACoFD, LASD air rescue and, if needed, Los Angeles City Fire Department, this is something Los Angeles is well capable of providing. If such a worst case scenario were to happen, the refining of multi-agency operations involving ground and air units from the recent training at Angeles National Forest will mean those tasked with the response are better prepared than ever.

When Wynn Resorts secured the sole Boston-area casino license, it took on the steep challenge of building a five-star resort in one of the oldest, most densely populated cities in the United States.With it, it inherited a pile of challenges: The T is too far from Everett, Sullivan Square isn’t walkable, a minor accident at rush hour can quickly turn Broadway into a parking lot. Locals feared that the casino’s popularity would turn downtown Everett into a parking lot during rush hour.Robert DeSalvio was barely two weeks on the job as president of Encore Boston Harbor when he heard these concerns.Five years later, company executives are preparing to open the $2.6 billion casino on June 23, potentially drawing tens of thousands of people that day to the 3.4-square-mile city of 46,000 people. In that time, DeSalvio and James Folk, head of transportation, have consulted engineers, bus companies, police officers and boating experts. They have come up with a series of public transit options for patrons coming from as far as Providence.“Wherever you’re coming from, there’s a way to get here without driving,” Folk said in an interview with MassLive.Wynn Resorts aims to bring up to 8 million visitors a year to Encore Boston Harbor, but officials hope they won’t disrupt traffic in the long term. If it works, the Everett casino could serve as a test for companies abroad considering casinos in urban centers.“This is the first resort built in an urban core ... They realize we’re going to have to create vehicular connectivity and public transportation connectivity to a resort if you put one in Yokohama or Tokyo or Osaka,” said Michael Weaver, spokesman for Wynn Resorts.The June 23 opening date seemed uncertain as Wynn Resorts faced a suitability review from Massachusetts regulators. The company ultimately paid a $35 million fine and a $500,000 fine against CEO Matt Maddox over their response to sexual misconduct allegations against founder Steve Wynn. The company agreed to have an independent monitor oversee operations and leadership training for Maddox as conditions to retain its casino license and run Encore Boston Harbor.With the suitability review behind them, company executives are focusing on preparing for the opening less than two weeks away. DeSalvio said he’s confident the company’s contingency plans will mitigate the traffic impact. The company just needs to convince visitors from across New England to give the alternative transportation options a chance and spare Everett the traffic jams.Parking at EncoreEncore Boston Harbor has only 2,900 parking spaces in its garage, a fraction of the spaces it would typically need to accommodate its patrons. There’s another 700 parking spots on the lot across the street at 31 Mystic St. By comparison, the smaller MGM Springfield casino and resort, which opened last August, has a 3,400 space parking garage.Don’t bother looking for a spot around the corner. The closest residential neighborhood, located nearly a half-mile up the street, was recently approved for 24-hour residential permit parking. Anyone who parks there without the permit sticker can get towed and face hundreds of dollars in fees. Encore Boston Harbor’s website also notes that Everett won’t have street parking.DeSalvio and Folk recommend that visitors rely on T and busses in the Greater Boston area or, for those outside of the region, take the commuter rail. For those who do drive in, the company secured another 5,000 parking spaces in lots off-site in hopes of keeping cars off the roads in Everett.There are 1,300 parking spaces at Wellington Station, 1,350 spaces at the Station Landing garage in Medford, 188 spaces at the Malden Station parking lot, 651 spaces at the Jackson Garage at Malden Center Station and 1,436 parking spaces at the Wonderland Station parking lot.Visitors could leave their cars at the station parking lot, paying under $10 to park, and hop on free bus shuttles provided by Encore to get to the casino.There is also parking lot on Rivergreen Drive in Everett, but that only has 625 spaces. Patrons who park there can get on the Neighborhood Runner, a free local shuttle bus that runs 24 hours, seven days a week.Folk also recommended that people coming from the west park their cars at the Alewife MBTA station parking lot, which has roughly 3,000 spaces. Visitors would need to take the Red Line inbound until Downtown Crossing, where they would need to switch to the Orange Line to get to Wellington station. The trip takes roughly 45 minutes.“We’re actually saying the whole MBTA network, utilize that to get you to Wellington station, and we’ll take it from there," Folk said.For those who do drive, Encore Boston Harbor put up signs to help direct drivers at the highways and rotaries near the casino. DeSalvio said the signs would hopefully cut down on people getting lost and disrupting traffic.“You don’t want somebody to get off, hang a right and go down Main Street into Charlestown if they’re coming to Encore Boston Harbor, exactly what the community didn’t want,” said DeSalvio, adding that the approval process alone took more than a year.Shuttle buses from MBTA stations, park and ridesWynn Resorts announced in March that Encore Boston Harbor would offer shuttle service to and from the Wellington and Malden Center stations. The shuttles are free and meet accessibility standards under the Americans with Disabilities Act.The Wellington station shuttle will run 24 hours a day, arriving every 10 to 20 minutes and heading to Encore Boston Harbor. The Malden Center station shuttle will run from 5 a.m. to 12:30 a.m., arriving every 20 minutes. That shuttle makes a stop at Wellington Station on the way to Encore Boston Harbor.Visitors taking the commuter rail into Boston can jump on the Orange Line toward Oak Grove and get off at Wellington Station.Encore Boston Harbor also plans to add regional buses will pick up guests from park and rides in Rockland, Millbury and Londonderry, New Hampshire. The three routes will have nine premium buses that seat 49 passengers.A shuttle bus will also be available on June 23 at the Wonderland stop on the Blue Line, but officials said that likely wouldn’t continue after Opening Day.Encore launched the 26-passenger coach bus called the Neighborhood Runner, which offers free shuttle service around Everett and Chelsea 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.Neighborhood Runner from ChelseaThe 26-passenger coach bus has stops at the Chelsea T station on the Silver Line, Everett City Hall, Rivergreen Drive and Encore Boston Harbor. The free shuttle runs every 20 minutes for 24 hours, seven days a week, Folk said.The service offers locals a safe alternative to driving or bicycling home if they’ve had too much to drink, which was a concern for some Massachusetts regulators when Encore executives requested to serve alcohol to active gamblers until 4 a.m.But perhaps the biggest beneficiaries are downtown Everett business owners. John Tocco, executive director of government affairs, told city councilors last week that he estimates the shuttle could bring potentially millions of patrons to the small businesses near city hall.The neighborhood shuttle service started running on Monday. Employees who live in Everett have already started using it to get to work, DeSalvio told MassLive.“What it’s telling me is this can work. This can work,” he said. “If you give them a convenient offer, you can get people to change their pattern a little bit.”Encore Boston Harbor, the casino and resort set to open in Everett in June 2019, is introducing water shuttle transportation across Boston Harbor and the Mystic River. Builders at BostonBoatwork in Charlestown showcased the luxury-style boat on Thursday, May 9, 2019. (Kristin LaFratta/MassLive)Water shuttlesEncore Boston Harbor envisions a transportation system that uses the coastline as an easier way to get around. Ignore the traffic, executives say, and sail on over on one of their four “mini-yachts."With the help of Charlestown luxury boat-builders Boston BoatWorks, Encore will deploy four, $1 million sleek water shuttles to connect South Boston to Everett. With plush white leather seating, varnished teakwood and flat-screen TVs, these vessels are made to match the luxurious atmosphere of the resort, spokespeople say.For an introductory fare of $7, the boats will run every 20-30 minutes between the east side of the World Trade Center in the Boston Seaport, to the north side of Long Wharf, to Encore in Everett. For those riding just between the Seaport and Long Wharf, rides will cost only $5. The shuttles seat up to 35 passengers per boat, are accessible to those with disabilities and will operate seven days-a-week, year-round from 7 a.m. to 12 a.m.According to Encore’s transportation executive Jim Folk, the shuttle will actually further connect the North Shore and South Shore by picking up where the MBTA leaves off. What may be an hour-long drive or train ride with multiple connections during rush hour could instead be a pleasant cruise from the Boston Seaport to the casino’s Mystic River port.Executives said they aimed to keep introductory fares low at $7 in order to encourage people to test the boats out. The hope is that passengers may become hooked, tell their friends, and popularize this less-conventional form of transportation.Those who have their own boat can also dock at the casino, though there are a limited number of docking spaces there and overnight docking will not be offered. The company has hired its own harbormaster to oversee water operations at Encore.Read more: Encore Boston Harbor introduces ‘premium’ water shuttles with $7 fares from Seaport, Long Wharf to EverettBluebikes in Boston.Bike share programEncore Boston Harbor is partnering with Metro Boston’s bike-share program Bluebikes. The biking rental system, operated by Lyft-acquired Motivate, is available in Boston, Brookline, Cambridge and Somerville and will now be accessible in Everett too, where competitor Lime has already made a footprint with its dockless bikes and electric bicycles.Encore announced sponsorship for Bluebike stations with 15 bikes each. One station will be located on-site, near the service road by the casino’s harbor walkway, and the second station will be located a short distance from Encore’s main entrance on Broadway.For those who wish to bring their own bikes to Encore, the resort will create an entire level of the parking garage that is dedicated to bicycle parking. On B1, 96 car-sized spaces will accommodate parking for up to 192 bicycles, according to Encore’s transportation presentation.In this Tuesday, Jan. 12, 2016, file photo, a driver displaying Lyft and Uber stickers on his front windshield drops off a customer in downtown Los Angeles. The Plain DealerSeparate lot for Uber, Lyft and other ride-hailing servicesPerhaps the most convenient way to get home from Encore Boston Harbor will be ordering an Uber/Lyft, especially in the early mornings when the MBTA is shut down. But that demand would mean more motorists riding around the streets waiting for a ride.Wynn Resorts used a patch of land across the street to build a lot to keep the ridesharing services, cabs and private limos off the road while they wait for passengers. The lot holds about 100 vehicles.The lot is still under construction, but the company plans to have it geofenced and ready by the time doors open.When a customer opens a ridesharing app or calls for a cab, the idea is that those drivers are already waiting in the lot, “so that they’re readily available, but they’re not driving around,” DeSalvio said.Sullivan Square MBTA Station in CharlestownWhat about employee parking? Massachusetts regulations require Encore Boston Harbor to offer its employees parking.None of the parking at the onsite garage is currently set aside for employees. The company agreed to set aside 800 spaces for its workers and has set aside 700 at the Station Landing parking garage in Medford. The company is in negotiations to set aside the other 100 employee parking spaces elsewhere.Encore Boston Harbor executives, however, hope the employees won’t need the spaces. They added incentives to keep its workers off the roads. The company covers MBTA monthly passes by 50 percent, up to $50, Folk said.The employees have their own 24-hour shuttle buses at Wellington station and access to the other shuttle services, like the rest of the public.Encore Boston Harbor Casino in Everett.Encore’s future transportation visionEncore executives envision a much more connected Metro Boston in the future, and they want their five-star casino and resort to be the impetus for transportation growth.DeSalvio, drawing on findings from the Lower Mystic Regional Working Group, feels development around Encore could make it a perfect hub for more public transportation routes.The president painted a future vision of a more interconnected Everett, Somerville, Medford and Charlestown. He pictures an extension of the Silver Line from Chelsea to Everett, connecting the MBTA route to Encore and continuing to Sullivan Square to meet the Orange Line. DeSalvio also said property behind the casino and resort is an ideal space for a commuter rail stop that could make the stretch of Broadway even more accessible to people outside of the Metro Boston area.In another move to simplify the visitor’s multimodal journey, DeSalvio said Encore is in preliminary talks to construct a pedestrian-friendly bridge across the Mystic River -- from Assembly Row and the MBTA Orange Line station there -- to Encore. The towering hotel is already visible to those waiting for the T at Assembly station, and in the near future it may be just a short walk away.As for water transportation, Folk thinks positive results in the water shuttle service could spur more coastal travel. Docks in Lynn, Salem and Quincy have expressed interest and could become potential destinations for the shuttles, depending on ridership.Though most of these future transportation plans are far from fruition, it is clear Encore has a mission to connect residents near and far to its resort grounds. Just how much Encore’s plans will ultimately benefit the transportation networks in Everett and Greater Boston remains to be seen.“At the end of the day, it’s going to be busy,” DeSalvio said. “We’re not in any way, shape or form saying we’re not going to be a very busy place, but the whole idea was to (a) mitigate our traffic and (b) come up with alternatives. I believe we’ve fulfilled that obligation.”

One year after a pledge died, San Diego State struggles to control its fraternities
- Share via
SAN DIEGO — It should have been a momentous night, the kind a fraternity pledge remembers forever.
Three months into his freshman year at San Diego State, Dylan Hernandez was going to learn the name of his “big brother” in a ritual at Phi Gamma Delta.
But not long after the celebration ended, tragedy struck.
Following a night of heavy drinking, the 19-year-old Floridian returned to his dorm, where he fell out of his bunk bed and struck his head. Students found Hernandez unconscious in his Tenochca Hall room and frantically dialed 911.
It proved to be a fatal blow. Campus police would later determine that Hernandez’s blood-alcohol level was, at one point, about 0.23%, almost three times the legal limit to operate a motor vehicle.
But as shocking as the death was, it fit a pattern. For years, San Diego State has been plagued by dangerous and sometimes illegal behaviors within its clutch of fraternities and sororities.
Now, one year after the tragedy, the scope of that misconduct is coming into focus.
An investigation by the San Diego Union-Tribune revealed that in the five years leading up to the accident, Greek chapters were widely and repeatedly called to account for a slew of violations. They allowed underage students to drink alcohol, performed abusive hazing rituals, and were accused of sexual harassment and assault, according to confidential records obtained through the California Public Records Act.
The disciplinary letters showed that 19 fraternities and sororities found themselves in some level of official trouble with the school from 2014 through 2019. That is nearly 40% of at least 49 Greek chapters that were active at the time.
The records describe raucous parties — some attended by hundreds of people — where kegs of beer, hard alcohol and drugs were on hand. They cite at least 18 instances of students being taken to hospitals after drinking too much or suffering some sort of injury, as well as descriptions of serious property damage, including one frat house that was later deemed “unlivable.”
Those 18 transports only reflect incidents that became part of a campus disciplinary procedure. San Diego State says 365 students were taken to hospitals for alcohol and drug-related issues from fall 2015 through fall 2019. The school is not sure how many of those incidents directly involved fraternities and sororities, which rule over the university’s party scene.
Most of the 41 disciplinary letters summarize San Diego State’s investigation into specific policy violations and detail the punishment and stipulations that resulted. Often the university required fraternities and sororities to take specific actions, such as attend educational workshops or develop safety plans for future events, before they could return to good standing.
Despite their bureaucratic language, the letters contain plenty of detail, giving a sense of what it’s like when Greek life goes awry.
The records describe two cases involving both a sorority and a fraternity that were accused of dissuading people who believed they had been drugged at parties from reporting the incident. In another instance, a fraternity held a “Career Day” event featuring a banner that was supposed to look like a porn star’s resume. Near the top was the name of a specific female student.
In one instance, a fraternity member who was serving as a “risk management” officer poured hard liquor down an ice luge for people to consume. A different fraternity engaged in hazing behaviors that involved “forced consumption of alcohol … and group violence” resulting in several injuries, records show.
One fraternity was put on interim suspension for reportedly forcing new members to live in a single room with a chicken. A sorority was put on probation after a midnight hazing ritual that made all of the pledges consider quitting.
The disciplinary records show that 12 of the 13 fraternities that were investigated by San Diego State from 2014 through 2019 violated policies multiple times over. In some cases, the violations occurred while the fraternity was still under sanctions from a previous incident. And suspending or expelling fraternities is a process that can take years.
San Diego State praises its Greek life program on its website, saying it helps students mature and prosper. As is true at other schools, most of these Greek organizations do not get into trouble, and many alumni of fraternities and sororities consider the experience a defining time of their lives.
But campus officials told the Union-Tribune that it regarded fraternities as “high risk” organizations because so many of them ran afoul of the university’s rules.
San Diego State’s Hernandez was one of at least 48 students to die in Greek-related incidents around the country from 2000 to 2019. Eleven of the deaths happened in California.
Florida State University suspended its entire Greek system following the death of a fraternity student. But the ban wasn’t permanent, and such episodes, locally and nationally, have not dimmed the appeal of fraternities and sororities.
Today, because of the coronavirus pandemic, most San Diego State students are taking classes online. But the party scene in the College Area community has continued to crackle. Health officials said students in that neighborhood contributed to the coronavirus outbreak that surfaced in August.
Since the fall semester began, more than 1,400 San Diego State students have tested positive for the virus, the highest number of any college or university in California.
The school staunched the outbreak, partly by confining residential students to campus dorms for part of September. San Diego State officials also roamed the streets of College Area, looking for students who were violating the COVID-19 rules.
On Oct. 30, county health officials took the unprecedented step of issuing cease-and-desist orders to eight College Area homes because they were rumored to be the sites for upcoming Halloween parties. Six of the homes were San Diego State fraternity and sorority houses, health officials said. University officials said they requested that the county take such action to help the school adhere to public health guidelines regarding COVID-19.
After Hernandez‘s death, university President Adela de la Torre created two task forces, one that examined student activities and safety and one that studied alcohol and drug misuse.
The groups, which were largely run by people who work or study at San Diego State, or alumni and school supporters, did not clearly quantify the depth of alcohol use and abuse among the school’s student body in general or Greek life in particular.
Nor did San Diego State seek to overhaul how fraternities and sororities operate, or provide a detailed account of why the school has so many medical transports.
Not all fraternity violations are serious. But the ones that are serious often have a common denominator: alcohol.
It’s a constant source of worry for college administrators nationwide. Even though most college students won’t be old enough to legally drink until they’re several years into their college experience, about 1,500 a year die of alcohol-related injuries.
About 30% of full-time college students ages 18 to 22 engaged in binge drinking in 2018, according to a large federal survey.
At San Diego State, the use of alcohol by the Greeks and the rest of the student body is so pervasive the university estimates that several thousand students would benefit from recovery programs.
The problem is central to the disciplinary record of Phi Gamma Delta, the fraternity where Hernandez drank during last year’s big brother-little brother ceremony.
According to university records, Phi Gamma Delta was repeatedly investigated for committing a series of violations in the years before Hernandez’s death.
As early as 2016, allegations of “ongoing hazing,” binge drinking and sexual assault were already being leveled at the fraternity.
One letter describes a Phi Gamma Delta social event in which two people were transported to a hospital, one for intoxication and one for an injury. During the same event, there was a report of a sexual assault that quickly resulted in a member being expelled from the fraternity, records say.
San Diego State put the fraternity on probation and required members to undergo a series of educational workshops in 2017. But that wasn’t the end of the trouble. Less than a year later, while the fraternity was still under sanctions from previous violations, the university began investigating a new incident in which Phi Gamma allegedly failed to responsibly handle alcohol and keep it away from minors.
Phi Gamma challenged the allegations but got pushback from university officials who suspected members of lying and retaliating against people who spoke out against the fraternity, records say.
“This behavior demonstrates that Phi Gamma Delta is more concerned with who the chapter believes ‘wronged’ the fraternity than holding chapter members and the organization accountable,” a disciplinary letter says.
The college placed new sanctions on the fraternity, but in early 2019 it was again accused of giving alcohol to underage people. Later that year, Hernandez died.
In August, the fraternity’s national office permanently suspended its San Diego State chapter, citing the university police department’s investigation into Hernandez’s death. The university also expelled the organization until 2030.
Robbins and Winkley write for the San Diego Union-Tribune.
